intro: Scirpus palustris, commonly known as marsh clubmoss, is a species of flowering plant in the family Cyperaceae. It is characterized by its tall, cylindrical stems and dense clusters of small, spike-like flowers. This plant typically grows in wetland habitats, such as marshes and swamps, where it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Its rhizomes are often used in traditional medicine for their purported healing properties. Scirpus palustris plays an important ecological role by stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various aquatic and terrestrial organisms.
